utterances: And so what are you going to do?
Well, we have--we're doing it one more time.
It's on auction right now for the month of August, and then we're done.
Don't plan on doing it again after that.
You know, a news article was written about you, and a Harvard psychologist, Susan Linn, was quoted as saying, `What this woman is doing is turning her child into an object to be bought and sold.'
I read that.
I think that's horrible, but, you know, everyone's entitled to their opinion, and there's going to be people who think I'm doing something horrible and people who think I'm doing something great.
I just need to take it with a grain of salt.
And we don't believe we're doing anything wrong, so we're just going to continue with it.
But GoldenPalace.com is a gambling site.
Right.
So are you promoting gambling?
I guess I would be.
But, you know, when my husband and I got married, we--our son was one.
And for our honeymoon we had gone to a casino, and we had gotten him a little T-shirt from the casino gift shop, so I don't see anything wrong with that.
So you don't see any difference between this and, for example, your baby wearing a baby Gap onesie?
Exactly.
I mean, we wear logos on our clothing every day, and we advertise for these companies for free.
So why not try and get paid for it, especially since the money, you know, will help us?
I'm a stay-at-home mom, and so this would really help with the baby's expenses and be able to put some money away for the two kids.
Michele Hutchison, good luck to you and good luck with your birth...
Thank you.
...next Tuesday, and thanks for joining us.
OK, Will, what's the challenge for next week?
I was raised in the Reform brand, which is the brand you're in when you're making the transition out of it completely.
That's the one where, it's the same - it's the same rules, the same basic rules as the other two, but not as much.
And certainly a lot of the ritual, but not like the Orthodox, not the dietary, you can kind of fudge on that.
You live in Maryland and you're not going to eat shellfish, OK, you're psychotic.
So there's certain things like that.
But it was a pretty - they were very good in terms of their - the temple I went to, they taught well.
I have to hand it to them.
It wasn't like, you know, it wasn't a silly kind of a thing.
It was actually pretty academic, in a way.
Including all those words you learned, antidisestablishmentarianism in Hebrew.
Yes.
And well, I learned, and I also got an award for Hebrew excellence.
I have three pins.
I wish I'd brought one to give you as a gift.
And yet, you don't describe yourself as a religious person today?
No!
The fastest way out of a religion is to be brought up in one, I think.
And the lack of a laugh in here scares me.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Really?
No, I was a wonderful Episcopalian as a child and I'm even a better one now.
I don't believe that.
I think, I just got - by the time I was 15, I was really - that was it.
The ritual didn't provide any kind of comfort.
When I return to the ritual, it provides no comfort.
I've had friends who've returned to the rituals and it seems to provide them with a comfort.
It never has.
There's always something that I either find irritating about it or it brings up a bad memory.
It just doesn't - it just it never worked.
I don't like sitting in a room with people and praying.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I don't.
It's not comfortable.
I don't find it comforting.
I find it comforting when there's tragedy and people gather, I find that comforting.
But for it's Saturday, let's get together.
No. No.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Do you find any similarities between comedy and religion?
Oh, yeah.
I think there's a lot.
They both take place on the weekends, and both of them have a certain call and response.
And I think laughter in the end provides a comfort for people.
And I know that from the comics that I know that have been approached, and I myself have been approached by people who talk about they had a father who was very sick or terminally ill.
I mean, it's amazing, and who listened to my material or other comics' material and it helped them.
Or people who say it helped them get through a tough time.
So I think, you know, I think organized religion could use some of that.
A good laugh.
Well, the concept of humor might help.
They're a little stiff.
Well, there were Catholic priests who would often get up and say hell and damn just to prove how liberal they were.
That always got a laugh.
Yeah.
And then they started playing the guitar, which really scared me.
As a theatre major, though, you say you were impressed with the Catholic mass.
I love the Catholic mass.
Early on before they got panicked and gave up Latin, wow, that was the best.
It was the best.
Tough to work with your back to the audience like that, though.
Well, they're moving around.
They've got kids going every which way.
And when you don't know what's going on, there's something special about it.
You know, when you're trying to figure it out and you're just thinking, this is some way to communicate.
And then they had the smoke, which was similar to the - I thought that was like signals like the Indians would have smoke signals.
They've got the water, the whole thing.
The little room to the side that people with - confession booths, candles everywhere.
It was a lot, I just thought a lot more theatrical than the way we Jews were handling it.
And then the way certain Christian sects, they dropped all that stuff.
That's the good stuff.
I really did, I liked that stuff.

And when we went to Europe, and I went to Europe as a kid, I - whenever I had the opportunity to race into a Catholic church to watch what was going on - because they seem to do it all hours of the day over there.
(Soundbite of laughter)
You get to Italy and it's 24 hours.
It's like, you know, that - the picture, you know, Jesus with his arms out, I used to call him.
He's like the Coke logo here.
He was everywhere in Italy.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I got a bigger laugh on that 10 years ago, OK?
Just so you know.
You're allowed to laugh at this stuff.
That lack of a laugh there is disturbing.
Your look of shock is bothering me.
(Soundbite of laughter)
It's unbelievable to be in a room - and I used to say it in a worse way and get a big - maybe I should have made it nastier.
Could have been.
Next time I will.
We're talking with - who else?
Lewis Black.
800-989-8255, if you'd like to join us.
His new book is called ""Me of Little Faith."" And let's get - who is this?
Brad on the line.
Brad's with us from Pinedale in Wyoming.
Yes.
Thank you for taking my call.
I was just wondering, what are your views specifically concerning Jesus?
My views particularly concerning Jesus are that, I mean, chances are he was around.
I think that's a real good possibility.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And - but whether he - I'm not - I don't buy the Son of God thing.
It's - if I don't buy Judaism, I ain't buying the son of God thing.
(Soundbite of laughter)
OK.
